content: The Act may be cited as the "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017". It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" defines key terms such as Administration, Administrator, air carrier, and appropriate congressional committees. The "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" defines terms like foreign air carrier, intelligence community, and secured area according to specific statutes and regulations. The "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" defines terms like Security Identification Display Area and Sterile Area according to specific regulations in title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations. SEC. 3. COST AND FEASIBILITY STUDY. The Administrator must conduct a cost and feasibility study within 180 days of the Act's enactment, in consultation with the Aviation Security Advisory Committee. The study will assess the impact of implementing secure doors with card and pin entry or biometric technology at various airports. The study will assess the implementation of secure doors with card and pin entry or biometric technology, surveillance video recording, and advanced screening technologies like magnetometers, explosives detection canines, and x-ray bag screening technology. The curr_chunk discusses the employee screening costs at airports that have implemented 100% screening of employees in secured areas. It includes costs of entry and exit points and compares the effectiveness of security features to the Federal Government and airports. The Comptroller General of the United States will assess the quality and reliability of the study on employee screening costs at airports with 100% screening in secured areas. The assessment report will be submitted to relevant committees within 60 days of receiving the study. The Comptroller General of the United States will report to the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation on the results of the review required for employee screening costs at airports with 100% screening in secured areas. SEC. 4. AIRPORT WORKER EDUCATION AND SECURITY AWARENESS. The Administrator will collaborate with various stakeholders to improve security awareness among airport workers regarding insider threats and access controls. Additionally, credentialing standards will be established in consultation with air carriers and airport operators. The Administrator will assess credentialing standards with stakeholders to address insider threats to aviation security. A report on the assessment results will be submitted to congressional committees within 30 days. The Administrator will require airport operators to submit social security numbers for individuals applying for access to the Security Identification Display Area to enhance security vetting. Failure to provide a social security number may result in denial of the credential. Additionally, the Administrator will issue screening requirements for airport operators to include in applications. Airport operators must inform applicants that employees with access to a Security Identification Display Area may be screened at any time. SEC. 5. SECURING AIRPORT WORKER ACCESS. The Administrator will collaborate with airport operators and the Aviation Security Advisory Committee to identify advanced technologies, including biometric identification, for securing employee access to airport secured and sterile areas. Additionally, within 180 days of the Act's enactment, all credentialed aviation workers requiring fingerprint-based criminal record checks will be continuously vetted through the FBI's Rap Back Service to swiftly detect and address insider threats to aviation security. The Administrator will enhance the Administration's ability to educate personnel on insider threats to aviation security and mitigate such threats by leveraging resources from the Department of Homeland Security and the intelligence community. Additionally, Playbook operations for employee physical inspections will be targeted and strategic. The Administrator conducts covert testing of employee inspection operations at airports to measure security effectiveness and provides results to relevant parties. The Administrator conducts covert testing of employee inspection operations at airports and provides recommendations for air carriers, foreign air carriers, and airport operators to conduct their own employee inspections. Additionally, the Administrator is required to submit an annual report on the effectiveness of employee inspection operations at airports for fiscal years 2018 through 2022. A centralized database must be established within 180 days. Within 180 days of the Act's enactment, the Administrator, in consultation with the Aviation Security Advisory Committee, must establish a national database of individuals who had their airport badges revoked for non-compliance with security requirements. Reporting mechanisms for air carriers, foreign air carriers, and airport operators to submit data on these individuals will also be determined. Establish a process for individuals to correct their records and remove their names from the database. The Department of Homeland Security leads insider threat coordination efforts at airports, working with other government entities, air carriers, foreign carriers, and airport operators. The Administrator must submit a plan for recurring reviews of security controls for airport IT systems within 90 days of this Act. No additional funds are authorized for these requirements.
